message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest a testicular cancer with elevated levels of HCG and AFP. Among the options, only embryonal carcinoma is associated with high levels of both hormones. Leydig cell tumor may cause elevated levels of testosterone but not HCG or AFP, metastasis to testis usually causes elevated LDH, and seminomatous germ cell tumor is associated with elevated levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) but not HCG or AFP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest that the most likely diagnosis is embryonal carcinoma. HCG and AFP are tumor markers for germ cell tumors, and elevated levels of these markers commonly suggest embryonal carcinoma. The presence of gynecomastia supports the diagnosis of germ cell tumor as Leydig cell tumors do not produce HCG or AFP. Metastasis to the testis is less likely as the left testis is normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s testicular mass and elevated HCG and AFP levels suggest embryonal carcinoma. Leydig cell tumors cause an increase in testosterone and estrogen, which should not cause gynecomastia. Metastasis to testis is rare, and seminomatous germ cell tumor usually presents with elevated LDH levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated HCG and AFP levels suggest Embryonal carcinoma, which is one of the subtypes of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors. Leydig cell tumors typically are not associated with elevated HCG and AFP levels. Metastasis to testis is unlikely given the history and physical examination findings. Seminomatous germ cell tumors are typically associated with elevated LDH levels, which is not seen in this case.

We refer to Mayo Clinic articles on testicular cancer for help. The elevated HCG and AFP levels indicate the presence of a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor, and the firm, nontender mass suggests an embryonal carcinoma. Leydig cell tumors are usually benign, and metastases to the testis are uncommon. Seminomatous germ cell tumors typically do not secrete AFP or HCG. Gynecomastia can also be seen with non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with testicular cancer, as he has a firm nontender testicular mass and elevated levels of HCG and AFP. Leydig cell tumors typically do not produce elevated levels of HCG or AFP. Metastasis to testis is possible but less likely given the patient’s medical history. Seminomatous germ cell tumors do not typically produce elevated levels of AFP. The most likely diagnosis is Embryonal carcinoma.

We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. The combination of elevated levels of HCG and AFP as well as gynecomastia suggests the most likely diagnosis is embryonal carcinoma, which is a type of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor. Leydig cell tumors do not produce HCG or AFP. Metastases to the testis are rare but can occur, and seminomatous germ cell tumors typically do not produce elevated levels of HCG. An ultrasound showing an enlarged testicle with a hypoechoic mass also supports the diagnosis of a germ cell tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s laboratory test results show elevated levels of both HCG and AFP, which are highly suggestive of embryonal carcinoma. Leydig cell tumors may lead to gynecomastia, but they usually do not produce elevated HCG and AFP levels. Metastasis to the testis is possible, but it is less likely given the patient’s history and the ultrasound findings. Seminomatous germ cell tumors usually do not produce elevated AFP levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a firm nontender mass that cannot be separated from the right testis and gynecomastia, suggestive of testicular cancer. Elevated HCG and AFP levels further support a diagnosis of germ cell tumor, specifically an embryonal carcinoma. Leydig cell tumors typically do not produce HCG or AFP, and metastasis to the testis, while possible, would not explain the elevated HCG and AFP levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated levels of HCG and AFP are indicative of embryonal carcinoma, which is a type of germ cell tumor commonly found in young men. Leydig cell tumor would produce testosterone but not elevate HCG or AFP. Metastasis to the testis is rare, and seminomatous germ cell tumors would elevate LDH but not AFP.
